meanings.definition: A piece of wood or metal on which something heavy can be slid or rolled along.
meanings.sent1: The workers used a skid to move the heavy crate across the warehouse floor.
meanings.sent2: The mechanic placed the engine on the skid to transport it to the assembly line.
meanings.sent3: The skid made it easy to move the large boulder in the garden.
meanings.sent4: The skid acted like a smooth conveyor belt for the logs in the lumberyard.
meanings.sent5: The skid helped the movers effortlessly shift the piano into the truck.

meanings.definition: To slide along a surface, typically sideways or out of control.
meanings.sent1: The car started to skid on the icy road, causing the driver to lose control.
meanings.sent2: The skateboarder accidentally skidded down the ramp and fell off.
meanings.sent3: The penguin tried to skid gracefully on the ice but ended up tumbling comically.
meanings.sent4: Her heart seemed to skid to a stop when she saw the unexpected sight.
meanings.sent5: The dancer's feet skidded across the stage, adding a dynamic element to the performance.

meanings.definition: To come to a sudden halt.
meanings.sent1: The car skidded to a stop just in time to avoid hitting the pedestrian.
meanings.sent2: The bicycle skidded to a halt as the brakes were applied abruptly.
meanings.sent3: The cat skidded to a stop when it saw the laser pointer dot on the wall.
meanings.sent4: Time seemed to skid to a halt as she waited for the exam results.
meanings.sent5: The train skidded to a sudden stop, causing everyone to lurch forward.
